awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Accurate Electrochemical Barriers Accelerated by Machine-learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (Peterson;1553365)

The study will promote advances in theoretical understanding of electrocatalysis as accelerated by machine-learning tools.  The resulting understanding will aid the development of related technologies such as solar-fuel devices, batteries, fuel cells and electrolyzers - all of relevance to renewable energy and the commercialization of sustainable technologies.  The research will also provide educational opportunities to students at various levels in both the U.S. and in rural Kenya, and will facilitate introduction of high-fidelity, accelerated atomistic calculations across a broad research community via the principal investigator's publicly available code, "Amp".

Electronic structure theory has revolutionized heterogeneous catalyst design in recent years, however it has had greater challenges in electrocatalysis due to the difficulty of calculating transition state energy barriers (which often dictate catalytic performance).  This study will provide the first systematic study of such potential-dependent electrocatalytic barriers across a range of catalytic materials and adsorbed reactants, thus facilitating the discovery of new materials and electrocatalytic processes.  The transition-state calculations will be enabled by the development of unique, atom-centered, machine-learning tools that dramatically accelerate atomistic calculations while matching the accuracy of computationally-intensive (and often exceedingly time-consuming) "ab initio" calculations.  The PI's Amp software modularizes atom-centered machine learning, and will be used to accelerate the search of potential energy surfaces for local minima, transition states, and global minima.  Moreover, the acceleration provided by machine learning will also facilitate the introduction of complicated phenomena associated with the electrochemical environment such as solvent effects and large unit cells of typical materials.  More broadly, the project will provide information that will be used by the PI as teaching tools to convey reaction visualization to students ranging from local high school and Brown undergraduate and graduate students to students at a new science and technology university (JOOUST) in rural Kenya.  Moreover, continued development of Amp, with new shared applications, will accelerate materials discovery across a broad range of applications related to energy and the environment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Electrochemical technologies are a crucial tool in a society that is transitioning to a low-carbon economy, as electrochemistry provides the bridge between electricity and chemicals. For example, batteries can provide short-term electricity storage to offset supply and demand mismatches on the electrical grid, or hydrogen can be synthesized from water and renewable electricity. Thus, electrochemistry provides a bridge to help create fossil-free materials and chemicals from renewable electricity sources.

In recent years, there has been great progress in the understanding and design of electrochemical processes from the atomic level up; that is, through first-principles calculations. Such atomistic simulations have the potential to provide fundamental insights that can allow us to overcome obstacles to the improved design of these crucial electrochemical systems. However, there are still great challenges to developing the atomic-level theory of these reactions.

In this project, we developed methods to allow us to calculate electrochemical reaction barriers in new, more efficient manners accelerated by machine learning techniques. We developed a way to perform constant-potential calculations in a machine-learning framework, which can allow a dramatic acceleration and provide access to simulations at much larger length- and time-scales. This allows for the simulation of realistic electrochemical phenomena at ab initio quality and the accelerated design of new materials.

We have also used these new techniques in order to develop new understandings of trends in electrochemical reaction barriers, which allows us to rationalize differences across electrode materials, and which can ultimately allow for a more systematic approach to electrocatalyst design through materials development.

The technologies developed within this project have broad societal impacts, as they help to enable future electrochemical technologies that are expected to be a key driver of our transition to a low-carbon economy. We have additionally performed a technology review of pathways for the chemical industry to take to lead to reduce its carbon intensity, with a focus on how electrochemical technologies can play a key role. We have additionally developed a web-based educational, interactive chemistry simulation based on the machine-learning approaches developed in this work. Several undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers were trained as part of this effort.


Last Modified: 06/08/2022
Modified by: Andrew Peterson
